journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of head trauma rehabilitation

title-group.article-title: Rehospitalization over 10 years among survivors of TBI: A National Institute on Disability, Independent Living and Rehabilitation Research (NIDILRR) Traumatic Brain Injury Model Systems Study

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. One Gustave Levy Place, Box 1163 New York, NY 10029. (p) 212-241-7587. (f) 212-241-0137

3Departments of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation and Ophthalmology, The University of Alabama at Birmingham. 700 S. 18th Street, Suite 200 Birmingham, AL

fn.p: We certify that no party having a direct interest in the results of the research supporting this article has or will confer a benefit on us or on any organization with which we are associated AND we certify that all financial and material support for this research are clearly identified in the title page of the manuscript.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: To describe the rates and causes for rehospitalization over 10 years following moderate-severe traumatic brain injury (TBI), and to characterize longitudinal trajectories of the probability of rehospitalization using Generalized Linear Mixed Models (GLMM) and Individual Growth Curve (IGC) models conditioned on factors that help explain individual variability in rehospitalization risk over time.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Secondary analysis of data from a multicenter longitudinal cohort study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Acute inpatient rehabilitation facilities and community follow-up.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Individuals aged 16 years and older with a primary diagnosis of TBI.

sec.title: Main Outcome Measures
sec.p: Rehospitalization (and reason for rehospitalization) as reported by participants or proxy during follow-up telephone interviews at 1, 2, 5, and 10 years post-injury.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The greatest number of rehospitalizations occurred in the first year post-injury (27.8% of the sample), and the rates of rehospitalization remained largely stable (22.1–23.4%) at 2, 5 and 10 years. Reasons for rehospitalization varied over time: Orthopedic and reconstructive surgery rehospitalizations were most common in Year 1, while General Health Maintenance was most common by Year 2 with rates increasing at each follow-up. Longitudinal models indicate multiple demographic and injury-related factors are associated with the probability of rehospitalization over time.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: These findings can inform the content and timing of interventions to improve health and longevity after TBI.
